MARKET RECAP

Twitter (TWTR) shares jumped after the company reported top and bottom-line beats, and daily average users (DAUs) numbers topped estimates. Coca-Cola (KO) shares moved higher after the soft drink maker reported a beat of top and bottom-line earnings expectations. Verizon (VZ) opened lower after the telecommunication co. reported a miss on top line earnings expectations. P&G (PG) traded lower despite the consumer goods maker beating top and bottom-line earnings expectations, perhaps as a result of falling revenue in its grooming and organic products areas. Pfizer (PFE) and Eli Lily (LLY) shares moved higher throughout the session on positive reports that the companies’ joint drug tanezumab is proving effective in osteoarthritis treatment. Hasbro (HAS) shares jumped higher after the toy maker reported a surprise profit in Q1. A strong earnings showing from Kohls Corporations (KSS) showed strong growth in foot traffic, hinting at a strong quarter for brick and mortar retailors. Lockheed Martin (LMT) and United Technologies (UTX) shares moved higher after both defence contractors beat earning expectations. Peers, including Northrop Gunman (NOC) and Raytheon (RTN) also moved higher in sympathy. Tesla (TSLA) opened lower following CEO Musk comments on future Model S/3/X weekly output and some criticism of the automakers self-driving technology from Consumer Reports. Qualcomm (QCOM) traded higher after Morgan Stanley upgraded the company to ‘overweight’. SPX +0.9% at 2933, NDX +1.26% at 7811, DJI +0.6% at 26656.

Monday's price action saw the curve bear-steepen; that steepening continued on Tuesday, but it was in a bull steepening fashion; most major curve spreads widened. An auction of 2s came in on the screws, with cover slightly softer than recent averages, and the internals weren't particularly great, with indirect bidders falling, seeing direct bidder participation rising - dealers were also larger participants than the prior auction. Ahead of tomorrow's 5s auction, the sector is set up and trades cheap on the curve compared with 2s and 10s, according to SocGen notes; it also trades cheap in asset swap versus older 5s. "While the dealer holdings of the 3-6y sector are the highest since December 2018, the current 5y benchmark trading special on repo (indicating a short base) is likely to help in the takedown of the auction," the bank says. It also notes that at pixel time, the WI trades above the stop-out rate of the previous auction, which could be supportive, and SocGen generally holds a positive bias going into the auction. US T-note futures (m9) settled 6 ticks higher at 123-04.

US MARKET WRAP 23 April 2019: Upbeat earnings pushes SPX to fresh closing high
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar up, Treasuries up, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: US new home sales beats; oil market willing to offset loss of Iranian crude; average US 2-year auction.

* AHEAD: Australian CPI; German Ifo; BoC Rate Decision & Press Conference; Supply from Germany, US and Italy; Earnings from Boeing, Caterpillar, Microsoft, Facebook, Tesla, AT&T, SAP, ABF, Novartis, Credit Suisse.

* SPX +0.9% at 2933, NDX +1.26% at 7811, DJI +0.6% at 26656. SECTORS: Communications +0.6%, Cons Discretionary +1.2%, Cons Staples -0.1%, Energy +0.0%, Financials +0.6%, Healthcare +1.6%, Industrials +0.9%, Materials +0.4%, Tech +1.13%, Telecoms +0.9%, Utilities +0.4%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Twitter (TWTR) shares jumped after the company reported top and bottom-line beats, and daily average users (DAUs) numbers topped estimates. Coca-Cola (KO) shares moved higher after the soft drink maker reported a beat of top and bottom-line earnings expectations. Verizon (VZ) opened lower after the telecommunication co. reported a miss on top line earnings expectations. P&G (PG) traded lower despite the consumer goods maker beating top and bottom-line earnings expectations, perhaps as a result of falling revenue in its grooming and organic products areas. Pfizer (PFE) and Eli Lily (LLY) shares moved higher throughout the session on positive reports that the companies’ joint drug tanezumab is proving effective in osteoarthritis treatment. Hasbro (HAS) shares jumped higher after the toy maker reported a surprise profit in Q1. A strong earnings showing from Kohls Corporations (KSS) showed strong growth in foot traffic, hinting at a strong quarter for brick and mortar retailors. Lockheed Martin (LMT) and United Technologies (UTX) shares moved higher after both defence contractors beat earning expectations. Peers, including Northrop Gunman (NOC) and Raytheon (RTN) also moved higher in sympathy. Tesla (TSLA) opened lower following CEO Musk comments on future Model S/3/X weekly output and some criticism of the automakers self-driving technology from Consumer Reports. Qualcomm (QCOM) traded higher after Morgan Stanley upgraded the company to ‘overweight’.

* WTI (K9) SETTLES USD AT USD /BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD AT USD /BBL. Crude prices kept climbing on Tuesday as the market continued to digest the expiry of US waivers on Iranian crude. In the fall out, several countries and institutions have publicly addressed their commitment to maintain a balanced oil market should Iranian supply fall to zero. OPEC sources stated that Gulf producers could increase their output in response to the drop in Iranian supply, but only if there is enough demand; the sources also said that May output will be higher than that of April, but still within the OPEC production target and that the rise is not related to Iranian sanctions. India’s Oil Minister Pradhan said India has a robust plan regarding supply to oil refiners and that there will be additional supplies from other major oil producing nations. The IEA said it sees global spare oil production capacity at 3.3mln BPD, and that it is ready to act to ensure the oil market is well supplied if necessary. Iran’s oil minister Zanganeh said that the US will not achieve its dream of bringing Iranian oil exports to zero, adding that the US has made a bad mistake by politicising oil and using it as a weapon. “As for the oil market, the immediate question is whether Monday’s price rally “got it right”,” Citigroup analysts comment. Elsewhere, underpinning the market in recent months is the prospect of a US-China trade deal materialising, however Citigroup goes on to suggest that the turn of events in Iran pose a risk to a deal, “China imported 585,000 bpd of Iranian crude oil during 2018 and has previously signalled that it doesn’t cooperate with unilateral sanctions,” adding that, “any Chinese refusal to cooperate with US sanctions would be a potential deal-breaker.” After the bell on Tuesday the API will release its read on US energy inventories for the prior week, which are likely to be less focused on this week following the Iranian sanctions. Crude stocks are seen building 1.3mln bbls, the products are both seen drawing, gasoline by 1mln bbls and distillates by 1.2mln bbls; Genscape forecasts the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub to show a build of 80k bbls.

* US NEW HOME SALES: US new home sales for March increased by 4.5% to a 692K-unit pace, beating the expected contraction of -2.5%, and holding pace with February’s figure which was revised up from 4.9% to 5.9%. “While existing sales were softer during the month, the housing market appears to be improving as the spring selling season gets underway,” Wells Fargo Economics’ analysts comment. During March approximately 50% of home sales occurred below USD 300k, above from 2018’s 43% average, “Builder discounting and a shift in focus toward building lower priced homes in more affordable areas continue to keep price increases in check,” Wells adds.

* BOC PREVIEW: Rate decision and Monetary Policy Report will be published at 1000 EDT/1500 BST on 24 April 2019; a press conference with Governor Poloz and Senior Deputy Governor Wilkins will take place at 1130 EST/1630 BST. The Bank is expected to keep rates unchanged at 1.75%. The latest MPR is expected to see 2019 growth projections trimmed; there will be focus on whether the Bank adjusts its estimate of neutral (currently 2.5-3.5%). Analysts will also be keeping an eye on whether the BOC drops its hiking bias. Click here for the full RANsquawk preview.

* NEC DIRECTOR KUDLOW: said that the Fed target rate should be lowered, reiterating comments made on 7 April and 29 March. He also noted further progress on the US/China trade front, with the two sides moving closer to a deal and considering a visitation exchange as part of the talks. Again, this is largely a reiteration of comments he made on 3 and 7 April. Weighing in on the effect of ending the Iranian oil waivers, Kudlow stated that the decision would not put upward pressure on oil prices and the markets are well supplied.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 6 TICKS HIGHER AT 123-04. Monday's price action saw the curve bear-steepen; that steepening continued on Tuesday, but it was in a bull steepening fashion; most major curve spreads widened. An auction of 2s came in on the screws, with cover slightly softer than recent averages, and the internals weren't particularly great, with indirect bidders falling, seeing direct bidder participation rising - dealers were also larger participants than the prior auction. Ahead of tomorrow's 5s auction, the sector is set up and trades cheap on the curve compared with 2s and 10s, according to SocGen notes; it also trades cheap in asset swap versus older 5s. "While the dealer holdings of the 3-6y sector are the highest since December 2018, the current 5y benchmark trading special on repo (indicating a short base) is likely to help in the takedown of the auction," the bank says. It also notes that at pixel time, the WI trades above the stop-out rate of the previous auction, which could be supportive, and SocGen generally holds a positive bias going into the auction.

* FX WRAP: The USD rose to near two-year highs on Tuesday; in the early part of trade, the complex took its cue from gold, where a large seller emerged, pushing gold down to 1266. The USD began ticking higher against most majors, and decent new home sales data for March – which was contrary to the weak existing home sales data for March – buoyed confidence, while a soft EZ consumer confidence report gave traders little reason to buy the EUR. Additionally, a widening Bund/BTP spread is beginning to re-assert influence on EUR (negative EUR). Other factors also played a role, analysts said, pointing to the effective Fed Funds Rate widening to a record 4bps over the IOER, with some suggestions that USD liquidity conditions were becoming tighter. GBP was lower on a combination of following the EUR (analysts note remind us of the correlation) and pressure ratcheting up on UK PM May to leave her role, while the aforementioned dollar was also singing the tune. Petro FX was mixed, with the RUB carving out another day of gains ahead of the CBR meeting later this week, though the NOK couldn’t gain against either the EUR or USD; neither could CAD ahead of tomorrow’s BOC meeting, where the central bank is seen holding rates, revising down near-term growth projections, and may be even dropping its hiking bias; as was Monday’s playbook, the oil importers were sold (INR, TRY, KRW) against the buck. The Aussie was also was a function of dollar moves, though traders now turn their attention to the Aussie CPI report due overnight, which is expected to disappoint to the downside, and add further weight to the argument that the RBA could pivot dovish later this year. EMFX succumbed to the dollar strength, though BRL was stronger, as the government reaches an agreement about the pension reform bill, with assurances that it had not been watered down.

subject: Does OPEC have enough spare capacity to offset the loss of Iranian exports? UBS thinks so; question is timing
content:
• UBS notes that Iranian production has fallen by around 1mln BPD from the 3.7mln BPD seen before sanctions were announced last year, and both production and exports should fall further over the course of 2Q/3Q19, the bank thinks. Initial pre-waiver estimates of lost production from Iran as a result of sanctions were in the 1.3mln to 1.7mln BPD range, which suggests an additional 300k BPD to 700k BPD of volume downside from current levels.
  • The catalyst for the next move is likely to be on the supply response from OPEC/OPEC+. Saudis have cut around 1.2mln BPD of production vs the 2018 peak, so there is an argument that there is capacity to offset lost Iranian crude exports, however, the question remains how quickly the US/Saudi/UAE will ramp production.
  • UBS says that OPEC and its OPEC+ partners (mainly Russia) had originally agreed to adjust planned production cuts to reflect unplanned outages, but despite major issues in recent months in Libya, Venezuela and Iran, no adjustment has occurred. The bank's strategists have taken this as unambiguous evidence that OPEC wants a higher oil price, and while that likely remains the case, the group will want to avoid prices high enough to become a drag on demand.  
  • The bank says that 19 May is the next OPEC ministerial meeting, ahead of the full OPEC meeting in June; while the meetings will help to provide clarity, desks do not rule out the potential of unilateral action before then.

subject: Brazil government whip says the lower house will form a Pension special committee on Thursday
TD Securities thinks it will be difficult for Brazil to pass pension reform before summer recess
content:
• The failure to hold a CCJ vote last week is evidence that the challenging politicallandscape in Brazil renders pension reform less likely to be passed before the summer recess, TD Securities writes.
  • The bank notes that sluggish growth, low yields, and political fighting over the reform process leave us with little good news on the horizon for BRL, while equities and fixed income appear to be 'priced-to-perfection'
  • "We expect a middling outcome for the reform, at a net savings in the realmof 650bn-750bn reais over the next 10 years," TD says, "While we suspect this would beneutral for equities and fixed income, there is more risk premium to be capturedin BRL which may present an opportunity in the second half of the year under a neutral-to-constructive reform outcome," and adds that "until the expected reform however, we see weakness in the real taking USDBRL back to 4.20."

PREVIEW: US Treasury to sell USD 40bln 2-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
* THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction USD 133bln in 2-year (USD 40bln, Tuesday), 5-year (USD 41bln, Wednesday), 7-year (USD 32bln, Thursday), as well as a 2yr FRN (USD 20bln, Wednesday); with USD 107.2bln maturing at month-end settlement, the auctions will raise a net USD 25.8bln in new cash. The Fed will allow USD 29.8bln to run off its balance sheet at month-end, and will add on a modest USD 0.6bln to 2s and 5s, USD 0.5bln to 7s, and USD 0.3bln to the FRNs.

* 2-YEAR PREVIEW: Recent auctions have been decent, with investors starved for returns, TD Securities said. "While the market has trimmed their pricing for Fed rate cuts to 12bp from 33bp in 2019, investors continue to expect cuts this year and in 2020," the bank says, "we believe that despite solid underlying fundamentals, expectations of a dovish Fed stance will help keep 10y rates pinned in the 2.40-2.60% range," and adds "we similarly expect the Treasury to trim 2-3y auction sizes, aiding demand at the front-end." Recent averages a stop on the screws with a 63% buyside takedown, the bank predicts. It also notes that the sector has cheapened on the curve, which might be supportive.

Daily FX Wrap: DXY eclipses 2019 high as Gold bugs bail out
content:
USD

The Dollar is now firmer across the board, with the DXY surpassing its previous ytd peak (97.783 vs 97.711 on March 7) at 97.704 having breached near term resistance (97.517), as several Usd/majors test recent and/or 2019 extremes. However, after a relatively subdued return from Easter and contained range for the Greenback overall, trade livened up on the back of activity in commodities and bullion where a hefty futures sale appears to have sparked tech stops on a break of the 21 DMA in Xau/Usd and knock-on selling. Chart-wise, a close above 97.640 may be key for further gains to 97.873 (Fib level) and then an approach towards 98.000.

CHF

The Franc looks set to end Tuesday’s EU session as the major underperformer as it slides through the psychological 1.0200 level vs the Buck and extends losses against the Euro to 1.1475 in wake of dovish comments from SNB chair Jordan last Friday (and namely that Swiss rates can turn more negative) at one stage.

AUD/NZD/CAD/EUR 

The next weakest G10 links as the Aussie and Kiwi both lose more ground to their US counterpart and test recent lows ahead of so called ‘flash crash’ troughs. Aud/Usd has fallen below the 55 DMA and a Fib (at 0.7111 and 0.7104 respectively) to sub-0.7100 and Nzd/Usd is under 0.6650 ahead of Aussie inflation data and NZ trade on Wednesday and Thursday. Similarly, the Loonie is back under 1.3400, ignoring a mixed Canadian wholesale trade update and latest rally in crude in advance of tomorrow’s BoC policy meeting and MPR that could be more dovish/downbeat, or at least cautious – preview recently posted via the Ransquawk headline feed. Elsewhere, the single currency lost sight of the 21 DMA (1.1251) and a hefty cluster of option expiries between 1.1250-60 (2.3 bn) on its way down through the pre-Easter low and a serious look at 1.1200 before support at 1.1187 and this year’s low so far at 1.1177.

NOK/SEK

Notwithstanding the aforementioned Euro declines vs the Buck, an element of risk aversion and bearish chart impulses prevented the Nok in particular from further oil-related gains as both Scandi currencies lost out to the Eur. Eur/Nok rebounded beyond 9.6000 at one stage and Eur/Sek only a few pips short of 10.5200.

GBP/JPY

Sterling eventually succumbed to overall Dollar strength, with Cable retreating all the way from 1.3000+ through the 200 DMA (1.2966) and March’s trough (1.2945) to circa 1.2930, but the Yen continues to hold up relatively well amidst UST yield retracement and less divergence vs JGBs in wake of the BoJ’s latest Rinban reduction. Indeed, Usd/Jpy only extended its topside to 112.03 before slipping back below the big figure.

EM

Choppy trade across the region, but ultimately losses vs the Usd as the Real awaits more on the Brazilian pension reform passage, the Rand suffers from latest Eskom funding shortfalls and the Lira suffers more Turkish political angst after the AKP’s request to rerun the Istanbul vote is turned down.

PREVIEW: BOC rate decision and MPR (April 2019)
content:
• The BOC will publish its rate decision and Monetary Policy Report at 1000 EDT/1500 BST on 24 April 2019; a press conference with Governor Poloz and Senior Deputy Governor Wilkins will take place at 1130 EST/1630 BST. The Bank is expected to keep rates unchanged at 1.75%. The latest MPR is expected to see 2019 growth projections trimmed; there will be focus on whether the Bank adjusts its estimate of neutral (currently 2.5-3.5%), and the output gap (currently -0.5%, range -1.0% to 0.0%). Fixed and FX latest: bond bears remain in control, as Buck bulls regain initiative
content: Core debt has bounced relatively well from worst levels, but EU bonds remain weak vs US Treasuries on Easter holiday grounds and the earlier return of the latter, with Bunds and Gilts still around ¼ point below par and midway between 165.13-164.71/127.05-126.74 Eurex and Liffe ranges respectively. However, Dollar buyers have returned to the fore and at least partly encouraged if not prompted by sales in Gold via futures and spot on a decent order that tripped technical selling. Indeed, the DXY has breached the topside of its intraday range and resistance just above 97.500 to 97.666, with the 2019 peak so far just a whisker away (97.711 from March 7).

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 23rd April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European indices are slightly subdued [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.2%] as markets trade largely in-line with indecisive overnight trade
  • UK MP’s return from recess with Labour-Tory talks resuming, recent newsflow surrounds potential no-confidence votes in PM May
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US New Home Sales, EZ Consumer Confidence (Flash), Supply from the US
  • Earnings: Verizon, P&G, eBay, State Street, Twitter, United Technologies, Lockheed Martin, Nextera

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed as sentiment somewhat deteriorated from the mostly positive close in the US, where the energy sector surged after the US decided to end Iranian oil sanction waivers but with gains in the broader market capped ahead of this week’s heavy slate of earnings. ASX 200 (+0.9%) was led higher by the energy sector after crude prices rallied around 3% to 6-month highs and NZX 50 (+0.5%) topped the 10K level for the first time ever, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) barely held on to early gains and stumbled from the weight of a firmer currency. Hang Seng (U/C) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were subdued after PBoC inaction resulted to a net liquidity drain of CNY 40bln which pushed the Overnight SHIBOR higher by over 27bps and with Hong Kong tentative amid resistance ahead of the 30K level and as its reflected on the recent mainland underperformance on return from its 4-day closure. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat after having recovered from earlier weakness as risk sentiment in Tokyo soured, while weaker results at today’s 2yr JGB auction also ensured price action was drab.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net drain of CNY 40bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7082 (Prev. 6.7035) UBS raised China 2019 GDP growth forecast to 6.4% from 6.1%. (Newswires) 

US

US President Trump will conduct a state visit to the UK in June and will visit Buckingham Palace. (Sky News)

UK/EU

UK Conservative Party activists are to hold an emergency summit for a vote of no-confidence in UK PM May after over 70 heads of local Conservative associations signed a petition calling for an extraordinary general meeting with PM May's position at the top of the agenda. Furthermore, reports added that the vote would be a non-binding vote but could pressure the 1922 Committee to take action to oust PM May. (Newswires/FT) A member of the 1922 committee stated that their leader Brady is set to meet the PM May this week to set a date for her departure with May 22nd or June 30th suggested, according to ITV's Brand. (Twitter)

1922 Committee Officer Evans says his recommendation is that we should say to UK PM May that she should go as quickly as possible, and if she refuses then the rules should be changed., talkRadio's Kempsell. (Twitter)

Brexit discussions between government ministers and Labour are due to resume today amid limited expectations of a breakthrough. (Guardian)

ECB's Coeure said negative rates are not the biggest problem for the banking sector and that banks should instead pay attention to costs, while he currently doesn’t see any monetary policy reason for tiered interest rates. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Salvini states that the government is not at risk and the contested growth boosting decree will be passed today without issue; follows previous reports that Italy could postpone growth pack approval to next Monday amind renewed tension in the ruling coalition. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European Indices are slightly subdued [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.2%], after being essentially unchanged for much of the session, with stocks largely following on from the indecisive sentiment seen overnight in Asia as participants return from the Easter weekend. Sectors are similarly mixed, although the significant outperformance in energy names continues following on from the lifting of Iranian waivers; as such Shell (+2.0%) are firmly in the green with the Co. also aided by the agreement to sell their 50% stake in SAREF to Saudi Aramco for USD 631mln. Due to the strong performance in Shell, alongside the Co. representing 11.3% of the FTSE 100 due to it having two listings in the form of A and B shares, the FTSE 100 (+0.4%) is outperforming its peers. Other notable movers this morning include Umicore (-15.4%) who are underperforming the Stoxx 600 following the Co. warning that 2020 revenue and earnings growth will be below expectations. Separately, Wirecard (-2.9%) are down after the expiration of BaFin’s short selling ban on Friday April 19th. Elsewhere, Thomas Cook (+16.3%) are soaring after reports that the Co. has received approaches for sections/entirety of the Co., with names such as Forsum International, KKR and EQT citied as potential bidders.

FX

DXY - The index remains firm and comfortably above the 97.000 handle within a 97.281-402 range amidst Greenback gains vs most major counterparts and EM rivals as the latest rally in oil prices continues to undermine crude importers and risk sentiment more broadly to the detriment of high beta currencies. However, the DXY still needs to overcome early April highs at 95.517 to expose ytd peaks posted in the previous month and virtually matching late 2018 levels just above 97.700.

CHF/AUD/NZD/NOK/SEK - The G10 laggards and largest losers against the buoyant Buck, as the Franc extends its decline further towards 1.0200 and through 1.1450 vs a relatively resilient Euro, while the Aussie and Kiwi hover closer to the bottom of 0.7140-10 and 0.6685-57 ranges vs their US peer on more dovish RBA and RBNZ policy leanings compared to the Fed. On that note, the Aud will be eyeing Q1 inflation data overnight amidst the consensus for a slowdown in q/q and y/y CPI rates with caution given latest RBA minutes revealing discussions about the conditions that may warrant a lower OCR including weaker price developments along with any deterioration in the labour market. Elsewhere, even the Nok is underperforming alongside the Sek as the Scandi Crowns fall victim to overall aversion rather than gleaning more support from the aforementioned advance in oil, as the former retreats to circa 9.5900 and latter to around 10.5000 vs the Eur.

GBP/JPY/EUR/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the Usd, as Cable recovers from pre-Easter lows to retest the 1.3000 level after holding above the 200 DMA (1.2966) and shrugging off heightened pressure on UK PM May as Parliament returns from its recess. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy remains capped just ahead of 112.00 within a 111.97-66 range and decent option expiry interest between 111.50-65 and 111.90-112.00 (1.1 bn either side). Note also, reported Japanese import and investor bids above 111.50 and the 200 DMA (111.51) may be curtailing a more concerted pull-back. Expiries could be impacting Eur/Usd as well given 2.3 bn rolling off from 1.1250 to 1.1260, while the Loonie is pivoting 1.3350 in the run up to Wednesday’s BoC policy meeting and press conference from Poloz and Wilkins – full preview of the event available on the Research Suite (along with a BoJ primer for Thursday).

EM - Most regional currencies are on the back foot vs the Dollar, as noted above, but the Rand is also factoring in renewed concerns about SA’s Eskom in wake of reports that the Government had to bail out the company to the tune of Zar 5bn to avert non-payment and a call on state guarantees – Usd/Zar currently at 14.1900+ vs sub-14.1500 at one stage.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds are still trying to stem losses after another downturn and brief breach of bearish technical levels between 164.80-78 to a fresh 164.71 Eurex low with the aid of further underperformance in Italian bonds and a near full point reversal from 130.11 in wake of official debt/GDP figures for 2018 showing an even bigger shortfall. However, core debt remains weak overall amidst the ongoing ramp up in oil prices and post-Easter correction to bear-steepening price action in US Treasuries that has only partially and marginally reversed. Ahead more US housing data and the Richmond Fed survey before the start of this week’s T-note supply and API stocks that could be pivotal in terms of the next move in crude.

COMMODITIES

Brent (+0.6%) and WTI (+0.8%) prices are in the green, as the oil complex extends on yesterdays gains following the US announcing that they are not going to extend waivers for Iranian oil, which expire on May 2nd. For reference, Iranian exports averaged 1.3mln BPD in March as such if the US are successful in their goal of reducing Iran’s exports to zero then this would result in a significant supply reduction; although, some analysts believe that the complete elimination of exports is unlikely. RBC state that they believe around 700-800K BPD to be removed from the market in the short term as a result of the waiver elimination. Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih stated that Saudi Arabia will cooperate with other oil suppliers in order to ensure that there is sufficient supply and that the market will not go out of balance. In light of the US’ announcement to not extend waivers Barclays sees upside risks of at a minimum USD 5/bbl for the USD 70/bbl Brent 2019 forecast if their exports drop to zero; however, Goldman Sachs state that the price impact will be limited and reiterates their 2019 Brent range of USD 70-75/bbl. Looking ahead, we have the API weekly crude release where the expectations are for crude stocks to build by around 0.5mln barrels.

Gold (-0.1%) is largely unchanged and trading within a narrow USD 4/oz range, largely in line with major stock indices and the generally indecisive risk tone as markets return from the extended Easter weekend. Elsewhere, the majority of steel mills in China’s Tangshan, Hebei province have been asked to cut around 40% of their sintering capacity due to the expected increase in pollution levels over the coming week.

China's Foreign Ministry says they have lodged representations with the US regarding their plan to end Iranian oil waivers. (Newswires)

Barclays sees upside risks of a minimum USD 5/bbl to its 2019 Brent Crude forecast of USD 70/bbl if Iran oil exports drop to zero. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs sees tightening of Iran oil sanctions to have a limited impact on prices this time and although it acknowledged near-term upside risks to prices, it reiterated fundamentally derived Brent price range of USD 70-75/bbl for the year. (Newswires)

subject: CHEAT SHEET: United Technologies (UTX) Q1 2019 earnings due 1155 BST/0655 EDT
content:
• Q1 EPS (USD): 1.71.
  • Q1 REVENUE (USD): 17.98bln.
  • EXPECTED FY 2019: At its previous earnings report, UTX guided FY 2019 earnings between 7.70 and 8.00 (was 7.61 in FY 2018); total revenues were guided in the 75.5bln to 77bln range.
  • CONSTITUENT: DJIA (3.5% weight), SPX (0.5% weight).
  • SECTOR: Industrials/Aerospace & Defense; peers: ARNC, BA, GD, HRS, HII, LLL, LMT, NOC, RTN, TXT, TDG.
  • MEAN ANALYST PRICE TARGET (USD): 143.33.
  • ANALYSTS: Of 23 analysts, 5 rate UTX a strong buy, 8 rate it a buy, 9 rate it a hold, 0 rate it a sell or strong sell.
  • RECENT RATING MOVES: 2 upgrades, 4 downgrades.
  • FACTORS: The company plans to split into three business units, if plans are approved to help drive greater value for shareholders. Q4 earnings were better than expected on the back of tax rates, aerospace business, continued passenger mile growth, and the contribution from Rockwell Collins, which was recently acquired (company expects it to be accretive to earnings in FY 2019). Look for commentary on a ramp-up of GTF Engine production, new products. Analysts are looking for continued growth in refrigeration and HVAC businesses. On the other side, analysts want to see some cost management, since if it remains unchecked, has the potential to weigh on profitability this year (cost of sales was running at 16.5% Y/Y in Q4); additionally, some analysts have wanted to see UTX keep an eye on debt levels, for the same reason. Given UTX aims to expand in foreign territories, it will be interesting to see the impact of FX.

Source: Barclays, RANsquawk, RBC, Refinitiv.

NOTE: RANsquawk is trialling this new format for US earnings previews and would welcome your feedback. For the Q1 2019 earnings season, we will be using this format to preview earnings for companies listed on the Dow Jones Industrial Average only.

  • Q1 REVENUE (USD): 7.89bln.
  • EXPECTED FY 2019 EPS (USD): KO guided FY EPS between 2.06 and 2.10
  • CONSTITUENT: DJIA (1.2% weight), SPX (0.8% weight)
  • SECTOR: Consumer staples/soft drinks; peers MNST, PEP. Also of note: STZ, UNA NA.
  • MEAN ANALYST PRICE TARGET (USD): 50.38.
  • ANALYSTS: Of 25 analysts, 4 rate KO at strong buy, 7 rate it a buy, 14 rate it a hold, 0 rate it a sell or strong sell. 
  • RECENT RATING MOVES: 3 upgrades, 4 downgrades.
  • FACTORS: What is the progress for new product innovations various new Coke flavours), while the beverage company will test a new energy drink in Spain and Hungary in the next quarter. There is some suggestion that the company’s guidance was too conservative vs the consensus, perhaps over uncertainties about FX. RBC says that even if KO does over-deliver this quarter on EPS (due to cost savings), it still does not expect a raise for the FY (since Q1 is a seasonally smaller quarter), and the bank thinks the biggest risk to KO’s EPS in 2019 is FX.
  • EXTERNAL FACTORS: Pepsi (PEP) reported sales growth of 5% in the quarter, on the back of a 1 point rise in volume growth and 4.5ppts rise in pricing. Constellation Brands (STZ) management said depletions were lower than shipments, due to poor weather in February. Unilever (UNA NA) reported 5% growth in Ems driven by 1.7% volume growth, with China and Brazil segments looking good; India was still decent but momentum eased. Management had hinted at some slowdown in US in Q4, and continued to decelerate through March.

Source: Barclays, RANsquawk, RBC, Refinitiv.

Expiries could be impacting Eur/Usd as well given 2.3 bn rolling off from 1.1250 to 1.1260, while the Loonie is pivoting 1.3350 in the run up to Wednesday’s BoC policy meeting and press conference from Poloz and Wilkins – full preview of the event available on the Research Suite (along with a BoJ primer for Thursday).

EM

Most regional currencies are on the back foot vs the Dollar, as noted above, but the Rand is also factoring in renewed concerns about SA’s Eskom in wake of reports that the Government had to bail out the company to the tune of Zar 5bn to avert non-payment and a call on state guarantees – Usd/Zar currently at 14.1900+ vs sub-14.1500 at one stage.

content: Gilts are extending losses alongside Bunds as tech selling through chart supports compound initial/early declines made on the back of significantly higher oil prices and bear-steepening in USTs following last Thursday’s upbeat US retail sales and jobless claims data. The 10 year UK debt future just hit a 126.85 Liffe base vs 127.05 at best and the 127.14 pre-Easter settlement, while the Short Sterling strip has reversed course after a relatively resilient start to sit between flat and 1 tick adrift. Back to bonds, the UK benchmark will be eyeing 126.83 and then 126.55 for support, while its Eurozone counterpart is testing the 164.80-78 area ahead of 164.59-56 before 164.33 (pre-Easter and flash PMI low).

subject: Bunds: bearish tone despite some supportive impulses
content: The 10 year German benchmark remains soft after an opening markdown to 165.01 vs Monday’s 165.22 close and slightly deeper dip below the big figure within a 164.92-165.13 range, even though US Treasuries have pared some losses and the curve has re-flattened partially. Moreover, Bunds are not deriving much traction from a more pronounced downturn in BTPs amidst more coalition wrangling in Rome that looks set to delay the unveiling of Italy’s growth plan until next week. Instead, the core Eurozone bond seems focused on the latest ratchet up in oil prices and taking heed of another ECB member downplaying the prospect of tiered deposits, at this stage – Coeure. Ahead, preliminary Eurozone consumer confidence.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

23rd April 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as sentiment somewhat deteriorated from the mostly positive close in the US, where the energy sector surged after the US decided to end Iranian oil sanction waivers but with gains in the broader market capped ahead of this week’s heavy slate of earnings. ASX 200 (+0.8%) was led higher by the energy sector after crude prices rallied around 3% to 6-month highs and NZX 50 (+0.6%) topped the 10K level for the first time ever, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) failed to hold on to early gains and stumbled from the weight of a firmer currency. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were subdued after PBoC inaction resulted to a net liquidity drain of CNY 40bln which pushed the Overnight SHIBOR higher by over 27bps and with Hong Kong tentative amid resistance ahead of the 30K level and as its reflected on the recent mainland underperformance on return from its 4-day closure.

* Note: Today’s equity sheet includes any news from 16:30 BST Thursday 18th April onwards due to the Easter Bank Holiday weekend.

FTSE

UK Retail Names – Indoor shopping centres saw a footfall decline of over 11% vs. Prev. on Friday and Saturday of the Easter Bank Holiday weekend, with a 10.4% footfall decline in non-food stores vs. Prev. High Street footfall +6.5% on Friday, and +1.2% on Saturday vs. Prev. (Guardian/Citi)

Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. have reached agreement with Saudi Aramco to sell their 50% stake in their SASREF joint venture for around USD 631mln, the sale is expected to be completed later on in 2019. (Telegraph)

Barclays (BARC LN) – Advisor Pirc has remained neutral regarding activist investor Bramson’s attempts to join the Co’s board, Pirc added that Bramson may be worth electing at next year’s annual meeting. Separately, Bramson is reportedly to increase pressure on the Co. if Q1 results disappoint Q1 results are expected on Thursday 25th April. Elsewhere, reports indicate that the Co. are planning on cutting investment banker bonuses as the division is underperforming (Times/Guardian/FT)

Taylor Wimpey (TW/ LN) – Co. are reportedly planning on giving their CEO Redfern a GBP 436k discount on a London apartment. Housebuilder shareholders have expressed concern that executive pay disputes may speed up the end of the Help to Buy subsidy scheme. (Times)

Anglo American (AAL LN) – Co’s advisors (Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, Centerview) are reportedly working on plans to prevent a takeover bid from Volcan Investments. (Telegraph)

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) – Co. are reportedly preparing to undertake their first share buyback in over a decade, of over USD 1bln. (Times)

Centrica (CNA LN) – Co. are reportedly planning to expand their software operations, to help revitalise their fortunes, relying on the increasing need for more flexible systems as the use of renewable energy grows globally. (FT)

Morrisons (MRW LN) – Co. are to appeal before the UK Supreme Court in an attempt to overturn a ruling from the Court of Appeals last year that the Co. are legally responsible for the data leak which was caused by an employee’s actions. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Thomas Cook (TCG LN) – Co. has reportedly received approaches for sections of their business alongside the entire Co. Some reports suggest that Forsum International may be a bidder for the Co.; who have recently increased their stake in the Co. to around 17%. Other reports indicate that KKR and EQT. Separately, USD 9bln US hedge fund Whitebox Advisors has built up a multi-million GBP short against the Co. (BBC/Sky/Times/Telegraph)

Hammerson (HMSO LN) – Investors are reportedly preparing to vote against the Co’s remuneration report at the upcoming general meeting, in-line with recommendations from ISS, a proxy advisor. (Sky)

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – Co’s founder Hill reportedly faces shareholder revolt after a major accounting mistake caused heavy investor losses; with one top backer reportedly stating that either founder Hill or CEO Donaldson should go following this. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

MAN GROUP (EMG LN) INTITATED WITH BUY AT BERENBERG

DAX

Wirecard (WDI GY) – BaFin’s short selling ban on the Co. expired on Friday 19th April. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Munich RE (MUV2 GY) – Co. are reportedly still looking to purchase specialised businesses according to Euro am Sonntag citing the CEO. (Newswires)

Uniper (UN01 GY) – Knight Vinke, a activist investor has stated the Co. should consider a deeper break up which would include spinning off Russian assets in order to pass antitrust issues that have prevented Fortum (FORTUM FH) from getting full control of the Co. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Faurecia (EO FP) – Q1 sales EUR 4.33bln vs. Prev. EUR 4.315bln. Co. affirms FY guidance; sales to outperform worldwide automotive production by 150-350bps. (Newswires)

TechnipFMC (FTI FP) – Co. have won a major contract for the development of ConocoPhillips TOR 2. (Newswires)

Casino (CO FP) – Co. has sold a 32 store portfolio to Apollo Global Management for EUR 470mln. Separately, Co. has expanded its partnership with Amazon (AMZO), with Amazon lockers to now be located in 1000 of the Co’s stores; with Co. branded products to be available on Amazon. Amazon’s partnership with Monoprix is also to be extended with Amazon Prime available outside Paris For reference, Casino are the Parent Co. of Monoprix. (FT/Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Airlines – European air freight volumes fell 7%, Asia falling 14%; according to the Cass Freight Index. (Newswires/Telegraph)

Juventus (JUVE IM) – Co. beat Fiorentina 2-1 to achieve a record extending eight sequential Serie A title; which is the first time a club has won 8 consecutive titles in one of Europe’s 5 major leagues. (Newswires)

Eni (ENI IM) – Co. along with Fincantieri (FCT IM), Terna (TRN IM) and CDP have singed a non-binding deal for the development of industrial scale wave power stations. (Newswires)

Fiat Chrysler (FCT IM) – Co. are recalling over 320k Dodge Dart vehicles in North America as rthey could ‘roll away’ due to a defect. (Newswires)

Atlantia (ATL IM) – Co. may join the rescue of Alitalia, in order to secure the backing of the government regarding the future of their domestic business after last years bridge collapse. (Newswires)

Prysmian (PRY IM) – Co. has refinanced their EUR 1bln long-term revolving facility with a collection of domestic and international banks. (Newswires)

ArcelorMittal (MT NA) – Co. has received a binding offer from Mutares to acquire the Co’s AreclorMittall Trefilunion SAS. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

Roche (ROG SW) – Co. has initiated a new Ventana HER2 dual-ISH companion diagnostic test for patients with breast and gastric cancer who are eligible for targeted therapy. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 23rd April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed as sentiment somewhat deteriorated from the mostly positive close in the US
  • UK Conservative Party activists are to hold an emergency summit for a vote of no-confidence in UK PM May
  • Oil prices extended on their gains overnight following the US announcement to end Iranian oil sanction waivers in an effort to push Iran oil imports to zero
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US New Home Sales, EZ Consumer Confidence (Flash), Supply from the US
  • Earnings: Verizon, P&G, eBay, State Street, Twitter, United Technologies, Lockheed Martin, Nextera

 

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed as sentiment somewhat deteriorated from the mostly positive close in the US, where the energy sector surged after the US decided to end Iranian oil sanction waivers but with gains in the broader market capped ahead of this week’s heavy slate of earnings. ASX 200 (+0.8%) was led higher by the energy sector after crude prices rallied around 3% to 6-month highs and NZX 50 (+0.6%) topped the 10K level for the first time ever, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) failed to hold on to early gains and stumbled from the weight of a firmer currency. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were subdued after PBoC inaction resulted to a net liquidity drain of CNY 40bln which pushed the Overnight SHIBOR higher by over 27bps and with Hong Kong tentative amid resistance ahead of the 30K level and as its reflected on the recent mainland underperformance on return from its 4-day closure. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat after having recovered from earlier weakness as risk sentiment in Tokyo soured, while weaker results at today’s 2yr JGB auction also ensured price action was drab.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net drain of CNY 40bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7082 (Prev. 6.7035) UBS raised China 2019 GDP growth forecast to 6.4% from 6.1%. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

UK Conservative Party activists are to hold an emergency summit for a vote of no-confidence in UK PM May after over 70 heads of local Conservative associations signed a petition calling for an extraordinary general meeting with PM May's position at the top of the agenda. Furthermore, reports added that the vote would be a non-binding vote but could pressure the 1922 Committee to take action to oust PM May. (Newswires/FT) A member of the 1922 committee stated that their leader Brady is set to meet the PM May this week to set a date for her departure with May 22nd or June 30th suggested, according to ITV's Brand. (Twitter)

Brexit discussions between government ministers and Labour are due to resume today amid limited expectations of a breakthrough. (Guardian)

ECB's Coeure said negative rates are not the biggest problem for the banking sector and that banks should instead pay attention to costs, while he currently doesn’t see any monetary policy reason for tiered interest rates. (Newswires) 

FX

 

In FX markets, the greenback was slightly firmer overnight following the mild bear-steepening in the yield curve during the prior session and as most major counterparts traded subdued. As such. EUR/USD was on the backfoot but with losses limited by a large option expiry of EUR 1.9bln at 1.1250 for today’s New York cut, while GBP/USD languished beneath 1.3000 as it braced itself for the resumption of Parliament and amid reports 1922 Committee Chairman Brady is to meet PM May this week to set a timeline for her departure. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses slipped to take out the prior day’s lows as price action began to pick up from the Easter lull and antipodeans were softer with AUD/USD dampened following the recent slip from its 200DMA, as well as ongoing consensus for looser RBA policy later in the year, but with downside stemmed by the oil price surge. 

COMMODITIES

 

Oil prices extended on their gains overnight with Brent Crude above USD 74.00/bbl and WTI Crude approached towards USD 66.00/bbl to print around 6-month highs following the US announcement to end Iranian oil sanctions waivers in an effort to push Iran oil imports to zero, while oil prices have also breached the 61.8% Fibonacci retracement level of the slide seen during Q4 last year. Elsewhere, gold was less eventful with the precious metal constrained by a slightly firmer greenback, as well as an indecisive risk tone which also kept the rebound in copper limited.

US decided not to renew any Iranian oil import waivers in May according to a White House Statement with the decision intended to bring Iran exports to zero, while the US, Saudi Arabia and UAE agreed to take action to ensure global demand is met and Iraq also commented that it is ready to increase their oil exports by 250k BPD based on needs of the market. (Newswires)

US administration official said between 700-800k BPD of oil is affected by ending Iranian waivers and sees no need to consider tapping SPR in the aftermath of ending waivers. The US is also to look for ways to prevent Iranian attempts to bypass sanctions and stated that a retaliatory move by Iran to close the Strait of Hormuz would be unacceptable, while a State Department Official said the Iranian waiver wind-down period will be one-year. (Newswires)

Iran stated that Tehran is in touch with partners regarding the end of US waivers and that the expiry of US waivers have no value, while it was also reported that Iran is to close the Strait of Hormuz if prevented from using it. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said the Kingdom would like to reiterate its longstanding policy of working towards oil market stability and will cooperate with other oil suppliers to ensure adequate supply. Furthermore, he added that they will consult with other oil producers over the next few weeks, that oil supplies will be available to consumers and the oil market will not go out of balance. (Newswires)

Barclays sees upside risks of a minimum USD 5/bbl to its 2019 Brent Crude forecast of USD 70/bbl if Iran oil exports drop to zero. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs sees tightening of Iran oil sanctions to have a limited impact on prices this time and although it acknowledged near-term upside risks to prices, it reiterated fundamentally derived Brent price range of USD 70-75/bbl for the year. (Newswires)

US

Action was thin, as players were away for the long-weekend. But the bias was towards bear-steepening, with shorter yields up around 1bps, while the long-end of the curve was up around 3bps by settlement. Reports suggested specs, day traders and dealers were sellers from the 10-year through the 30-year space, with HFs selling across the curve. Some had also suggested that the sharp rise in oil prices was applying upwards pressure on yields. US T-note futures (M9) settled 6+ ticks lower at 122-30.

US President Trump will conduct a state visit to the UK in June and will visit Buckingham Palace. (Sky News)

US President Trump said Herman Cain requested not to be nominated to the board of the Federal Reserve and that he will respect Cain’s wishes. (Newswires)

PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE NEWS: Taiwan Export Orders fell 9.0% Y/Y in March
content:
TAIWAN

Chunghwa Telecom (24512 TT) - Co. promotes its President to the position of Chairman and CEO. (Newswires)

Data Recap 

  • Taiwan Export Orders (Mar) Y/Y -9.0% vs. Exp. -5.0% (Prev. -10.9%). (Newswires)
  • Taiwan Unemployment Rate (Mar) 3.7% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 3.7%)

 

SINGAPORE

CapitaLand (CAPL SP) - Co. announces sale of Storhub Self Storage for SGD 185mln. (Newswires)

Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT SP) - Co. reports Q2 DPU of SGD 2.40 vs, Prev. SGD 2.40 Y/Y, rev. SGD 30.4mln vs. Prev. SGD 33.0mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Frasers Property (FPL SP) - Co. Australia unit JV with Sekisui House will sell remaining 3 retail assets in One Line. (Newswires)

Keppel REIT (KREIT SP) - Co. acquires 99.4% stake in Seoul office building T Tower for SGD 301.4mln. (Newswires)

subject: Fuji Electric (6504 JT) may report FY oper. profit increased 5% Y/Y to JPY 59bln vs. guidance of JPY 58bln
